hidden bottom systems, molecular tetraquarks, complex scaling method

I introduction

During the last two decades, many new hadron states have been observed in the large scientific facilities, which triggered plenty of theoretical interest and revitalized the study of hadronic spectroscopyÂ Hosaka:2016pey ; Lebed:2016hpi ; Chen:2016qju ; Ali:2017jda ; Esposito:2016noz ; Dong:2017gaw ; Guo:2017jvc ; Olsen:2017bmm ; Karliner:2017qhf ; Liu:2019zoy ; Brambilla:2019esw ; Bicudo:2022cqi ; Mai:2022eur ; Barabanov:2020jvn ; Chen:2022asf . Past researches show that some of the new hadrons are hard to classified into the conventional mesons or baryons. Then, new effective degrees of freedom need to be introduced and more complicated configurations named exotic states emerge. Beyond the traditional quark-antiquark and three-quark pictures, quantum chromodynamics (QCD) actually allows the existence of plentiful hadronic structures, such as molecular states, compact multiquarks, hadro-quarkonium, hybrid states, glueball and their mixtures. Since many new particles lie near the hadron-hadron thresholds, the picture of hadronic molecule is significantly competitive among these theoretical interpretationsÂ Chen:2022asf ; Dong:2017gaw ; Guo:2017jvc ; Karliner:2017qhf ; Zou:2021sha ; Mai:2022eur ; Zou:2013af . Thus, it becomes a primary task to pick out the genuine molecular states from lots of candidates and predict more ones for experimental searches.

Among lots of molecular candidates, the states composed of ground state hadrons attract great attentions both experimentally and theoretically. The longstanding charmonium-like state Xâ¢(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872)italic_X ( 3872 ) was first observed in the process BÂ±superscriptğµplus-or-minusB^{\pm}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Â± end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTâ†’â†’\toâ†’KÂ±â¢Ï€+â¢Ï€âˆ’â¢J/Ïˆsuperscriptğ¾plus-or-minussuperscriptğœ‹superscriptğœ‹ğ½ğœ“K^{\pm}\pi^{+}\pi^{-}J/\psiitalic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Â± end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J / italic_Ïˆ by the Belle Collaboration in 2003Â Belle:2003nnu , which opened a new era in the investigations of exotic states. III.3 Further discussions

We collect the final results of B(s)(âˆ—)â¢BÂ¯(s)(âˆ—)subscriptsuperscriptğµğ‘ subscriptsuperscriptÂ¯ğµğ‘ B^{(*)}_{(s)}\bar{B}^{(*)}_{(s)}italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( âˆ— ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_B end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( âˆ— ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT systems in TableÂ 4. Our results show that the bound states or resonances appear in the J=0ğ½0J=0italic_J = 0 and 1 systems, while the formation of molecules in J=2ğ½2J=2italic_J = 2 systems is harder. Meanwhile, both bound states and resonances are found in the I=0ğ¼0I=0italic_I = 0 systems, while only several bound states exist in the I=1ğ¼1I=1italic_I = 1 systems. That is to say, the systems with higher isopsipn or spin are harder to form molecular states than the lower ones. In present work, the J=2ğ½2J=2italic_J = 2 or I=1ğ¼1I=1italic_I = 1 case has less channels compared with others, which suggests that the coupled channels may play crucial roles to obtain these molecules. Moreover, the dependence on spin and isospin for potentials is also reflected by the Clebsch-Gordan coefficients, which determines the relative sign and strength.

The importance of coupled channels effects is reflected in the formation of those bound or resonant states in TableÂ 4. IV Summary
